intro: Ophrys tetraloniae var. gresivaudanica, commonly known as the Gresivaudan orchid, is a rare and specialized orchid species native to the alpine regions of Europe. It is characterized by its intricate, lip-like structure that mimics the appearance of female insects, a feature that plays a crucial role in its pollination strategy. The plant typically grows in rocky or gravelly soils at high altitudes, where it thrives in cool, moist conditions. Its flowers are usually pale yellow to greenish in color, with intricate patterns that aid in attracting specific pollinators. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a vulnerable species, requiring conservation efforts to ensure its survival.
